div.head: Materials and Methods
div.p: All chemicals and solvents were purchased from commercial suppliers (Sigma, Acros, Enamine and Fluka) and were used without further purification. LB medium and 2xYT were purchased from MP Biomedicals, LLC (California, USA) and Sigma-Aldrich (Missouri, USA). Hemin chloride and Œ¥aminolaevulinic acid were purchased from Merck Millipore (Darmstadt, Germany) and Acros Organics (Geel, Belgium). H-His(3-Me)-OH (NMH) was bought from Bachem (Bubendorf, Switzerland). Glucose oxidase was obtained from TCI (Tokyo, Japan). PEG1500, bovine liver catalase, and lysozyme were purchased from Sigma (Buchs, Switzerland). Phusion High-Fidelity DNA polymerase, T4 DNA ligase and all restriction enzymes used in this study were purchased from New England BioLabs (Massachusetts, USA). Oligonucleotides were synthesised by Microsynth AG (Balgach, Switzerland).

All NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian Oxford 300 MHz or Bruker Ascend 400 MHz spectrometer in D2O or CDCl3 and are referenced to the residual solvent peak. Data for 1 H NMR are reported as follows: chemical shift (Œ¥ ppm), multiplicity (d = doublet, t = triplet, q = quartet), coupling constant (Hz), integration. Data for 13 C NMR are reported as follows: chemical shift (Œ¥ ppm). All UV-vis spectra were recorded on Perkin Elmer Spectrometers of the Lambda series (25, 35 or 45) at 20 ¬∞C. Depending on the enzyme concentrations, cuvettes with path lengths of either 1 cm, 2 mm or 1 mm were used. The scan speed was 960 nm/min. For GC analysis, Thermo GC-FID equipped with a Thermo Scientific TR-5MS (30 m x 0.25 mm) 260F142P column was used. The heating rate was chosen as follows: 60 ¬∞C for 1 minute, heat to 200 ¬∞C at a rate of 20 ¬∞C/min, heat to 300 ¬∞C at a rate of 30 ¬∞C/min, and hold at 300 ¬∞C for one minute. Enantiomeric excesses were determined on a Jasco2080Plus supercritical fluid chromatography (SFC) instrument using a Daicel Chiralcel OJ-H column. As eluent, 100% carbon dioxide was used at a flow rate of 2 mL/min. The product was detected at 200 nm. Fast protein liquid chromatography (FPLC) was carried out on an NGC Quest 10 plus chromatography system (Bio-rad laboratories, California, USA) equipped with a multi-wavelength detector, BioFrac fraction collector and a Superdex 75 increase 10/300 GL (GE healthcare Life Sciences, Illinois, USA) size exclusion (SEC) column. Sodium dodecyl sulphatepolyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) was performed on a PhastSystem electrophoresis apparatus using precast PhastGel homogeneous 20.0 (GE healthcare Life Sciences). High-resolution mass spectra were recorded on an electrospray ionisation quadrupole time-of-flight (ESI-Q-TOF) MaXis system (Bruker Daltonics, Bremen, Germany) coupled to an Agilent 1200 HPLC system (Agilent technology, California, USA). Steady-state and pre-steady state stopped-flow experiments were performed on an Applied Photophysics SX18 stopped-flow spectrophotometer (Applied Photophysics Ltd., Leatherhead, UK) equipped with a xenon arc lamp and a 1 cm path length.

Continuous wave (CW) EPR spectra were recorded on an ElexSys E680 spectrometer (Bruker, Rheinstetten, Germany). Q-band (~34 GHz) pulsed experiments were performed on an ElexSysII E580 spectrometer (Bruker, Rheinstetten, Germany) featuring a 200 W traveling wave tube amplifier and a homebuilt resonator accepting EPR capillaries with an outer diameter of 3 mm. Using helium gas flow cryostats Oxford ESR900 (Oxford Instruments, Oxfordshire, UK) for CW experiments and an Oxford CF935 (Oxford Instruments, Oxfordshire, UK) for pulsed experiments, all EPR data were measured at 10 K. All reported X-band CW spectra are displayed at a common microwave (mw) frequency of 9.5 GHz after appropriate scaling of the magnetic field axis. 4096 points spectra were measured under non-saturation conditions, i.e. at nominal mw power of either 0.20 mW (30 dB, high spin Fe(III)) or 795 nW (54 dB, low spin Fe(III)). The magnetic field modulation amplitude was set to 0.5 mT and the lock-in amplification to S3 100 kHz. For the conversion time and time constant, 327.68 ms and 81.92 ms were used, respectively. Each raw data trace was subjected to a magnetic field offset, polynomial baseline and experimental resonator background correction. For each measurement session, the magnetic field was calibrated against a diphenyl picrylhydrazyl (DPPH) standard (g = 2.0037 ¬± 0.0001) and measurement of an EPR capillary containing exclusively the used buffer-glycerol mixture, yielded the corresponding background signal. The latter was smoothed and subtracted from the raw data trace. The resulting background corrected spectra were baseline corrected using a first order polynomial term. Q-band echo-detected field sweeps (EDFS) 1 of 8192 points were obtained using mw pulses as described below for hyperfine sublevel correlation (HYSCORE) experiments. The 24 ns wide integration window was placed symmetrically with respect to the echo maximum. HYSCORE 2 measurements were carried out using a ùúã 2 ‚ÅÑ -œÑ -ùúã 2 ‚ÅÑ -ùë° 1 -ùúã -ùë° 2 -ùúã 2 ‚ÅÑ -ùúè -ùëíùëê‚Ñéùëú pulse sequence, with mw ùúã 2 ‚ÅÑ and ùúã pulse length of 12 ns. The time interval t1 and t2 were both initiated at 128 ns and incremented by 8 ns time steps. HYSCORE data for ùúè values 128, 150 and 196 ns were recorded and averaged at two field positions, which are specified below. An eight-step phase cycle ensured selection of the appropriate coherence transfer pathway. A polynomial baseline correction and Hamming window were applied to the time-domain HYSCORE data. Subsequent zero filling and twodimensional Fourier transformation of the real part resulted in HYSCORE spectra in the frequency domain. Spectral simulations were carried out with the EasySpin 3 saffron function.

General Procedures (A) Plasmid construction. Genes encoding wild-type sperm whale myoglobin and the His93NMH variant in pET29b (pET29b_Mb and pET29b_Mb His93NMH) were described previously 4 . Two additional mutations (H64V, V68A) were introduced into the pET29b_Mb and pET29b_Mb His93NMH plasmids by overlap extension PCR in two steps. First, two fragments were synthesised with the primer pairs Mb_NdeI(+) / Mb_H64V(-) and Mb_H64V(+) / Mb_XhoI(-) (Supplementary Table 5). The two PCR products were purified and then combined in an equimolar ratio for the final PCR. The full-length fragments were assembled using the primer pair Mb_NdeI(+) and Mb_XhoI(-). The mutated fragment was digested by NdeI and XhoI and ligated into pET29b(+). Secondly, using the resulting plasmids as templates, two fragments were synthesised with the primer pairs Mb_NdeI(+) / Mb_V68A(-) and Mb_V68A(+) / Mb_XhoI(-) (Supplementary Table 5). The two PCR products were purified, combined and used for the final PCR with the primer pair Mb_NdeI(+) and Mb_XhoI(-). The mutated fragment was digested by NdeI and XhoI and ligated into pET29b(+) as described above. The sequences of the resulting constructs pET29b_Mb H64V V68A (the corresponding protein product called Mb*) and pET29b_Mb His93NMH H64V V68A (the corresponding protein product called Mb*(NMH)) were confirmed by the DNA sequencing service provided by Microsynth AG and shown below. 5 . For expression of Mb*, pET29b_Mb H64V V68A was transformed into BL21(DE3) E. coli and the cells were plated on a LB agar plate containing 50 Œºg/ml kanamycin. A single colony of freshly transformed cells was cultured overnight in 3 ml of LB medium containing 50 Œºg/ml kanamycin. 1 ml of the culture was used to inoculate 100 mL of 2xYT medium supplemented with 1 mM Œ¥-aminolaevulinic acid (1M stock) and 50 Œºg/ml kanamycin. The culture was incubated for ~2 h at 37 ¬∞C at a shaking speed of 230 rpm. When the OD600 of the culture reached 0.4 to 0.5, IPTG was added to a final concentration of 0.1 mM to induce expression of the Mb* protein. For expression of Mb*(NMH), pET29b_Mb His93NMH H64V V68A and pEVOL_PylRS(NMH) were transformed into BL21(DE3) E. coli and the cells were plated on an LB agar plate containing 50 Œºg/ml kanamycin and 34 Œºg/ml chloramphenicol. A single colony of freshly transformed cells was cultured overnight in 3 ml of LB medium containing 50 Œºg/ml kanamycin and 34 Œºg/ml chloramphenicol. 1 ml of the culture was used to inoculate 100 mL of 2xYT medium supplemented with 1 mM Œ¥-aminolaevulinic acid, 12 mM H-His(3-Me)-OH (NMH), 50 Œºg/ml kanamycin and 34 Œºg/ml chloramphenicol. The culture was incubated for ~2.5 h at 37 ¬∞C at a shaking speed of 230 rpm. When the OD600 of the culture reached 0.4 to 0.5, IPTG and arabinose (10% stock in water) were added to a final concentration of 0.1 mM and 0.05%, respectively.

The induced cultures were incubated for ~24 h at 25 o C, and the cells were subsequently harvested by centrifugation at 8,000 g for 10 min. The pelleted bacterial cells were suspended in PBS buffer (Na2HPO4 10 mM, KH2PO4 1.8 mM, NaCl 137 mM, KCl 2.7 mM pH 7.4) and sonicated to disrupt the cells. To maximise haem occupancy, Mb* and Mb*(NMH) were reconstituted with hemin chloride. Briefly, the lysate solutions were rapidly mixed with 0.2 mM of hemin chloride (20 mM stock solution in 10 mM NaOH), and incubated at 4 ¬∞C for 10 min. The lysate was centrifuged at 11,500 g for 15 min and the supernatant was subjected to affinity chromatography using Ni-NTA Agarose (Qiagen, Helden, Germany). After two washes with buffer containing 50 mM Tris-HCl, 300 mM NaCl and 10 mM imidazole at pH 8.0, the proteins were eluted by 50 mM Tris-HCl, 300 mM NaCl at pH 8.0 containing 300 mM imidazole. The protein solutions were then subjected to size-exclusion (SEC) chromatography on Superdex 75 10/300 increase GL (GE healthcare Life Sciences) with a flow rate of 0.7 ml/min using an NGC Quest 10 plus FPLC system equilibrated with PBS. The fractions were monitored at 260, 280, and 408 nm, collected using a BioFrac fraction collector, and analysed by SDS-PAGE. If necessary, the protein solution was concentrated by Amicon Ultra-15 10 kDa cut-off centrifugal filter device (Merck Millipore, Massachusetts, USA). The concentrations of haem proteins were determined by UV-vis absorbance measurements at 407 nm using an extinction coefficient determined by the haemochrome assay (see below).

(C) Crystallisation and structure determination. Mb* and Mb*(NMH) in PBS buffer were concentrated to approximately 45 mg/ml using an Amicon Ultra-15 10 kDa cut-off centrifugal filter device. The protein solutions were passed through a Zeba spin desalting column pre-equilibrated with pure water, and the final concentration was adjusted to 30 mg/ml. The proteins were crystallised by vapour diffusion in sitting drops at 20 ¬∞C. An initial crystallisation hit was identified in a well containing 0.1 M succinic acid, sodium dihydrogen phosphate glycine (SPG) (molar ratio 2:7:7) buffer at pH 7.0 containing 25% (w/v) PEG1500 by using the commercial The PACT Suite sparse matrix screen (Qiagen). Crystallisation conditions were improved by varying the buffer pH and the concentration of PEG1500. The optimal crystallisation conditions were found to be 0.1 M SPG buffer at pH 6.8-7.2 containing 28-32% (w/v) PEG1500. Crystals were cryo-protected by plunging into mother liquor supplemented with 20% (w/v) ethylene glycol prior to flash cooling in liquid nitrogen. Diffraction data were collected at 100 K using a wavelength of 1.000 √Ö at the Swiss Light Source (SLS). The structures were solved by molecular replacement using an atomic resolution myoglobin structure (PDB ID: 1A6K) or a Mb structure bearing an NMH ligand (PDB ID: 5OJ9) and further refined using the program PHENIX. Refinement statistics are summarised in Supplementary Table 4. Complexes with EDA and ethyl acetate were prepared and analysed as described in the Methods section of the main text.

(D) UV-vis measurements. All spectra were recorded anaerobically in 50 mM potassium phosphate buffer at pH 8.0. Enzyme and reactant concentrations were chosen as indicated in each experimental section.

(E) Haemochrome assay. In order to determine the haem occupancy of Mb* and Mb*(NMH), a haemochrome assay was carried out following a slightly modified literature procedure 6 . A solution of pyridine-NaOH was prepared by mixing 1 mL of pyridine with 0.4 mL 1 M NaOH and removing the excess aqueous phase. To a cuvette containing 700 ¬µL degassed protein solution in 50 mM potassium phosphate buffer pH 8.0, 250¬µL pyridine-NaOH and 50 ¬µL of dithionite solution (10 mg/mL in 50 mM potassium phosphate pH 8.0) were added anaerobically. The UV-vis spectra were recorded and the concentration was determined using an extinction coefficient Œµ556-540= 22,100 M -1 cm -1 7 . Determination of the concentrations was performed in triplicate.

To determine the extinction coefficients of the ferric myoglobin variants, the UV-vis spectrum of 1 mL protein solution (protein concentration previously determined by haemachrome assay) in 50 mM potassium phosphate buffer pH 8.0 was recorded. By plotting the measured absorbance values of the Soret bands against protein concentrations, the extinction coefficients, Œµ407, for Mb* and Mb*(NMH) were determined to be 148,000 M -1 cm -1 and 151,000 M -1 cm -1 , respectively.

(F) Reduction potential determination. Reduction potentials were determined using a slightly modified literature procedure 8 . Before the measurement of the reduction potential was carried out, a solution of toluidine blue (5 mg/mL) was titrated into a cuvette containing 50 mM potassium phosphate buffer pH 7.0 to produce a maximum UV-vis absorbance around 0.3. The determined volume of dye to produce this absorbance was then used in all further experiments. For reduction potential measurements, 50 mM potassium phosphate buffer pH 7.0 containing 10 mM glucose and 300 ¬µM xanthine was made anaerobic by bubbling nitrogen for 10 minutes through the buffer in a 1 mL cuvette sealed with a septum. Then toluidine, enzyme (2 ¬µM final concentration), 30 ¬µL catalase (stock 10 mg/mL) and 10 ¬µL of glucose oxidase (stock 5 mg/mL) were added. To initiate the reaction, 2 ¬µL of 25 ¬µM xanthine oxidase solution was added. The reactions were monitored by UV-vis for approximately 30 minutes and the data plotted using Kaleidagraph (Supplementary Figure 5A). The reduction potential was determined by adding the standard reduction potential of toluidine blue (E¬∞ = +34 mV) to the value of the y-intercept obtained by fitting the data to the Nernst equation (Supplementary Figure 5B). All potentials are referenced to a normal hydrogen electrode (NHE) 8 .

(G) Kinetics of myoglobin reduction. Reduction of the myoglobin variants was too fast to monitor by conventional UV-vis spectroscopy, so the reactions were analysed in a stopped-flow device. Changes in intensity of the Soret band were monitored upon 1:1 mixing of anaerobic 20 ¬µM myoglobin solutions with dithionite solutions of different concentrations (1 to 30 mM in 50 mM potassium phosphate buffer at pH 8.0). To extract the rates, the observed decrease in absorbance at 407 nm was fitted to an exponential decay using the Kaleidagraph software. The rate constant was determined by plotting the fitted exponential rates against dithionite concentration (Supplementary Figure 4A). Dithionite concentration was determined spectrophotometrically using a molar extinction coefficient of 8,043 M -1 cm -1 at 315 nm.

(H) Stopped-flow kinetics of carbenoid formation. Formation of the Mb*(NMH) carbenoid was too fast to observe by ordinary UV-vis spectroscopy. Therefore, stopped-flow was used to monitor the reaction. The Soret band was monitored upon 1:1 mixing of an anaerobic 40 ¬µM solution of Mb*(NMH) in 50 mM potassium phosphate pH 8.0 buffer and an anaerobic EDA solution (concentrations between 6 and 120 mM) in 50 mM potassium phosphate pH 8.0 and 10% (v/v) methanol. The observed decrease in absorbance at 407 nm was fitted to an exponential decay using Kaleidagraph software. The rate constant was determined by plotting the fitted exponential rates against EDA concentration (Supplementary Figure 4B).

(I) EPR Measurements. Samples were prepared anaerobically in PBS at pH 7.4 containing 40% (v/v) glycerol at protein concentrations of 0.5 and 1.0 mM based on their UV-vis absorbance. 0.5 mM protein concentration were used to record continuous-wave (CW) EPR spectra, while pulsed EPR measurements required 1.0 mM protein concentration to achieve higher spin concentration and reduce measurement time. EDA or 13 C-labelled EDA was added to the mixture, affording a final concentration of 50 mM and 1 M for CW and pulsed EPR measurements, respectively. Shortly after addition, ~40 ¬µL sample was transferred to an EPR quartz tube of ~3 mm outer diameter and flash-cooled in liquid nitrogen. After EPR characterisation by CW measurements, representative samples were thawed and diluted in degassed 50 mM potassium phosphate buffer (pH 8.0). UV-vis spectra were recorded immediately to confirm the integrity of the carbenoid species.

(J) Monitoring inactivation of Mb* and Mb*(NMH) by porphyrin alkylation. Inactivation experiments were run using a modified literature procedure 9 . Reactions were run anaerobically on a 1 mL scale using 60 ¬µM enzyme and 20 mM EDA. After stirring the solutions for 1 h in sealed vials, the reactions were quenched by adding 100 ¬µL of 3 M hydrochloric acid. The aqueous phase was extracted twice using a 9:1 mixture of methylene chloride and methanol. The solvent was evaporated in vacuo. The porphyrin products were re-solubilised in 100 ¬µL methanol and analysed by LC-MS (detection at a wavelength of 330 nm) as well as HR-MS.

div.head: Synthetic Procedures (A) Cyclopropanation reactions.
div.p: The cyclopropanation reactions were run on a 400 ¬µL scale in 2 mL sealed glass vials. The enzyme (final concentration: 10 ¬µM) was added to degassed 50 mM potassium phosphate buffer pH 8.0 and the solution was made anaerobic by continuous headspace exchange with wet nitrogen gas for a minimum of 10 minutes. The reactions were initiated by adding dithionite (40 mM stock solution in 50 mM potassium phosphate buffer pH 8.0), styrene (10 ¬µL of 400 mM stock in methanol) and EDA (10 ¬µL of 800 mM stock). For reactions under non-reducing conditions, dithionite was excluded. The reactions were stirred at 230 rpm using a magnetic stirring bar and quenched with 100 ¬µL of 3 M hydrochloric acid at appropriate time points. For product quantification, 100 ¬µL of 5 mM 1,2dimethoxybenzene in chloroform was added as standard and the product was extracted with 900 ¬µL chloroform. The product was quantified by GC-FID analysis using calibration curves prepared from authentic standards (Supplementary Figure 9B).

(B) Determination of Enantiomeric Excess. Cyclopropanation reactions were performed as described above. The reaction mixtures were extracted with 400 ¬µL hexane, centrifuged at 10,000 g for 1 minute and the supernatant was analysed by supercritical fluid chromatography using a Jasco SFC system. The results are listed in Supplementary Table 1.
(C) Synthesis of 13 C-EDA. The 13 C-labeled compound was prepared from 2-[ 13 C]glycine in a two-step synthesis following a reported literature procedure 10 .

div.head: Synthesis of ethyl-2-[ 13 C]glycine hydrochloride
div.p: 2-[ 13 C]Glycine (99%, 0.5 g, 6.6 mmol, 0.5 eq) was suspended in 10 mL ethanol and the mixture was cooled to -15 ¬∞C (ice-salt bath), and SOCl2 (1.5 mL, 20.7 mmol, 1.6 eq) was added slowly. The mixture was stirred until it reached room temperature and another half equivalent of 2-[ 13 C]glycine (99%, 0.5 g, 6.6 mmol, 0.5 eq) was added. The mixture was refluxed for 2 h and then recrystallised from ethanol. Yield (1.45 g, 79%).

div.head: Synthesis of ethyl-2-[ 13 C]diazoacetate ( 13 C-EDA)
div.p: Ethyl-2-[ 13 C]glycine hydrochloride (1.45 g, 10.4 mmol, 1.0 eq) was mixed with water (4 mL) and DCM (8 mL) in a round bottom flask and cooled to -5 ¬∞C (dry ice, H2O/MeOH). An ice-cold solution of sodium nitrite (1 g, 10.6 mmol, 1.2 eq in H2O) was added, then a solution of sulfuric acid (1.2 g, 12.2 mmol, 1.18 eq) in water (5% (w/w)) was slowly added. The mixture was stirred for 45 minutes. The organic phase was extracted with DCM (2x10 mL) and washed with a saturated NaHCO3 solution (15 mL) and water (15 mL). The water phase was extracted with DCM (2x10 mL). The combined organics were dried over Na2SO4, filtered and concentrated in vacuo. Yield (0.67g, 56%). The product was used without further purification.

div.head: EPR Measurements (A) CW measurements.
div.p: The CW spectra characterise Mb*(NMH) (Supplementary Figure 10A and Supplementary Table 2) as a high-spin Fe(III) species (HS, S = 5/2) of axial symmetry (HS 1, 62.5 %) with a smaller contribution from rhombic symmetry (HS 2, 37.5 %). In contrast, the high-spin Fe(III) species of Mb* is exclusively of rhombic symmetry (Supplementary Table 2), while signals of both Mb*(NMH) and Mb* feature spectral intensities around g = 6 and 2. Two low-spin (LS) Fe(III) species (S = 1/2) are formed shortly after addition of EDA to Mb*(NMH) (for 13 C EDA: Supplementary Figure 10B and Supplementary Table 2). Both display a rhombic symmetry, while the major LS contribution LS1 shows g principal values between 2.54 and 1.93 (Supplementary Table 2). The coordination environment of Fe(III) LS species in haem proteins can be classified based on so-called truth tables introduced by Blumberg and Peisach 11 . Supplementary Figure 14 assesses the ligand-field of LS Fe(III) as a function of rhombicity (V/Œî) and tetragonal field (Œî/Œª). Where V and Œî correspond to the rhombic and tetragonal splitting of the t2g orbitals derived from a ligand field of octahedral symmetry. In combination with the spin-orbit coupling constant Œª, the ligand-field parameters V/Œî and Œî/Œª can be calculated according to Taylor 12 . EDA coordination to Mb*(NMH) leads to an Fe(III) LS species with uncommonly large tetragonal field values of |Œî/Œª| >16 (Supplementary Figure 14). With respect to rhombicity, the EDA-induced LS species of Mb*(NMH) displays a coordination closer to axial symmetry than other reported myoglobin variants.

Spin concentration was quantified by double integration of the CW spectra and comparison to the double integral of a reference sample of known concentration, namely a 500 ¬µM Mb*(NMH) sample for the HS species and a 2.0 mM [K3Fe(CN)6] sample as a Fe(III) LS reference (Supplementary Figure 11). For double integration, the spectral data were linearly baseline corrected before each of the two integrations. The Matlab package EasySpin 3 was used for spectral simulations. CW spectra were computed with the EasySpin pepper function.

For quantification of the Fe(III) HS and LS contributions to signal observed upon addition of both EDA and single 13 C-labelled EDA to Mb*(NMH), non-saturated CW spectra were double integrated over corresponding field regions (Supplementary Figure 11). Double integration resulted in a ~800 ¬µM LS contribution, which was obtained after subtraction of the HS contribution (Supplementary Figure 11B and D, blue). The double integral of the LS species is affected by the error in the subtraction since the spectral HS intensity around g = 2.0 overlaps with the LS signal. Hence, an error of 0.1 and 4% is introduced in the quantification of the LS spin concentration for EDA and single 13 C-labelled EDA, respectively. The difference in error originates from the roughly tenfold higher HS contribution of ~470 ¬µM in case of single 13 C-labelled EDA in comparison to ~40 ¬µM in case of EDA. In addition to the uncertainty associated with subtraction of this HS contribution, other sources of error influence the determined spin concentration. These include variation in the initial Mb*(NMH) concentration (estimated up to 10%) as well as variation in the EPR sample volume (visually estimated to be up to 25 %), due to N2 gas formation during the reaction. Error estimates here refer to determination of absolute concentrations, while the relative CW EPR spectral intensity was found to be reproducible. Taken together, the Fe(III) spin concentration agrees with the initial Mb*(NMH) concentration of 500 ¬µM upon sample preparation within our admittedly large experimental uncertainty.

(B) HYSCORE measurements. HYSCORE spectra of the Fe(III) LS intermediate were recorded at two field positions B0,x and B0,y associated with its gx and gy principal values as specified in Supplementary Figure 12A. Note that no HS contribution was observed in the Q-band EDFS, in contrast to the corresponding X-band CW spectrum (Supplementary Figure 10B). The 14 N and 13 C regions of the HYSCORE spectra are shown in Supplementary Figure 12B and C, while Supplementary Figure 13 displays the corresponding 1 H region.

The hyperfine coupling to the 13 C-labelled terminal carbon of EDA is evident from the cross peaks around the 13 C Zeeman frequency in Supplementary Figure 12B and C (thick, dashed line). These peaks are split by axial hyperfine coupling of [10.5, 10.5, 18.5] ¬± 0.5 MHz with a tilt of the hyperfine tensor versus the g tensor of [0¬∞, 20¬∞, 0¬∞], as determined by spectral simulation (red). Additional simulation parameters used with the EasySpin function saffron are g = [2.54, 2.06, 1.93] with a Gaussian distribution of [0.17, 0.033, 0.028] and a pulse excitation bandwidth of 100 MHz. In addition, coupling to 1 H is observed by a weak yet significant set of cross peaks around the 1 H Zeeman frequency in Supplementary Figure 13 (thick, dashed line). This characteristic signal can be simulated by an axial hyperfine coupling of [-2.5, -2.5, 8.0] ¬± 0.5 MHz (Supplementary Figure 13, red), along with a broad 1 H matrix peak on the diagonal at the 1 H Zeeman frequency due to several (unresolved) protons in the vicinity. Additional simulation parameters were used as described above for the 13 C simulations.

div.head: Quantum Chemical Analysis Thermochemical Analysis of Iron Porphyrin Carbene Reactivity
div.p: For our theoretical analysis of the iron porphyrin carbene (IPC) complex with a proximal Nmethylimidazole ligand, we introduce different energy measures and contributions that are defined in Supplementary Table 6. The definitions are based on the standard model of gas-phase thermochemistry, which assumes a complete decoupling of all degrees of freedom (electronic, vibrational, rotational and translational), harmonic vibrations, a rigid rotor, and the particle-in-a-box model for translational motion. Within this model, rotational and translational partition functions can be calculated from the equilibrium coordinates of the atomic nuclei alone, whereas the vibrational partition function requires a quantum chemical frequency analysis.

In the following sections, we carefully discuss all energy measures and contributions defined in Supplementary Table 6 to provide a reliable thermochemical description of the stability and reactivity of the IPC complex. Although we are considering a condensed-phase system, the thermochemistry of which is usually hard to model, our discussion will reveal that the standard model of gas-phase thermochemistry can be harnessed to derive sensible corrections to the electronic energy of condensed-phase systems. The thermochemical energy that we propose to use as an approximate enthalpy, Happrox (Supplementary Table 6), neglects translational and global rotational motion.

div.head: Computational Details
div.p: All electronic-structure calculations were carried out with the Gaussian 09 suite of programs 13 (see Tables S7, S8, and a zip directory with xyz files (see supplementary materials) for an overview of all species and elementary reactions considered). We performed PBE 14 /def2-TZVP 15,16 and PBE0 17 /def2-TZVP structure optimisations and also PBE0/def2-TZVP and B3LYP* 18 /def2-TZVP single-point calculations on the PBE/def2-TZVP optimised structures. To keep the notation uncluttered, we denote these approximations PBE//PBE, PBE0//PBE0, B3LYP*//PBE, and PBE0//PBE, respectively. Here, the first label refers to the density functional employed for a single-point electronic-energy calculation on the optimised structure obtained with the density functional denoted by the second label. For structure optimisations of open-shell singlet states, we performed a single-point calculation of the triplet state on the optimised triplet structure and subsequently optimised it in an unrestricted Kohn-Sham frame-work with an equal number of Œ±and Œ≤-electrons such that S = MS = 0 ("chkbasis" and "guess=mix" keywords in Gaussian 09). The PBE//PBE Hessian of the electronic energy with respect to the nuclear coordinates was calculated to analyse thermochemical energies of the species and reactions studied.

To obtain guess structures for a transition-state search, we performed relaxed scans (PBE/def2-SVP 15,16 ) of internal coordinates (in steps of 0.1 √Ö or 0.004 √Ö for bond lengths and 10¬∞ for torsional angles) expected to be important for the transition studied. The maximum-energy structure of the relaxed scan was subjected to a transition-state optimisation (PBE/def2-TZVP) based on the quadratic-synchronous-transit method 19 ("opt=qst3" keyword in Gaussian 09), which also requires the two corresponding minimum-energy structures. We found that the minimum-energy structures for the reactions with EDA and styrene are so different from the transition-state guess that we considered those structures from the relaxed scan adjacent to its maximum-energy structure. Subsequently, reactants and products were validated by following the intrinsic reaction coordinate 20 (PBE/def2-TZVP) from the optimised transition state ("irc" keyword in Gaussian), with a full structure optimisation of the resulting reactants and products.

div.head: Structure and Stability of the Bridged IPC Complex
div.p: We truncated the protein crystal structure of the IPC complex (bridged configuration) to the minimal (generic) model shown in Supplementary Figure 19.

In our theoretical analysis, we considered the low-spin state, the intermediate-spin state, and the highspin state of the formal iron oxidation states +II (neutral species, 1) and +III (cationic species, 1 + ), respectively, for molecular-structure optimisations. Relative energies and structural parameters are summarised in Tables S9-S11.

The PBE//PBE results suggest that the singlet state of 1 is slightly more stable than the triplet state (8.5-13.0 kJ mol -1 ) and significantly more stable than the quintet state (63.5-71.2 kJ mol -1 ). By contrast, the PBE0//PBE results suggest that the singlet state of 1 is significantly less stable than both the triplet state (40.5-44.9 kJ mol -1 ) and the quintet state (17.8-25.4 kJ mol -1 ). For 1 + , the findings are similar. The PBE//PBE results suggest that the doublet state is more stable than the quartet and sextet states (22.9-28.5 kJ mol -1 and 93.2-103.8 kJ mol -1 , respectively), whereas the PBE0//PBE results suggest the quartet state to be more stable than the doublet state (18.0-23.5 kJ mol -1 ), or balanced energetics between the doublet state and the sextet state, i.e., -0.2-10.4 kJ mol -1 with respect to the doublet state.

We demonstrated more than 15 years ago that spin-state energy splittings depend linearly on the exactexchange admixture so that pure density functionals favour low-spin states, whereas hybrid density functionals favour high-spin states 18,21,22 . We defined the B3LYP* density functional 18 with a reduced exactexchange admixture of 15% (instead of 20% in B3LYP) to yield more reliable spin-state energy splittings, especially for iron compounds (note that PBE0 contains a 25% exact-exchange admixture).

The B3LYP*//PBE results (Tables S9 and S10) suggest the triplet state of 1 to be slightly more stable than the singlet state by 14.3-18.8 kJ mol -1 , whereas the singlet state is, analogously to PBE//PBE, clearly favoured over the quintet state (44.4-52.1 kJ mol -1 ). Similarly, we find balanced energetics between the doublet and quartet states of 1 + (the quartet state is 2.4-8.0 kJ mol -1 higher in energy) and a distinct destabilisation of the sextet state over the doublet state (45.4-56.0 kJ mol -1 ). Combined with the PBE//PBE results, we expect the low-spin and intermediate-spin states of 1 and 1 + to be potentially relevant from a thermochemical perspective.

In comparison to the crystal structure (Supplementary Table 11), the only reasonable optimised structure obtained from both PBE and PBE0 is that of the low-spin state. For PBE, the Fe-C1 and Fe-N1 bond lengths are overestimated by all optimised structures (0.05-0.26 √Ö and 0.08-0.49 √Ö, respectively), whereas the C1-N1 bond length is estimated fairly accurately by most optimised structures (max. 0.07 √Ö deviation from crystal structure). In cases where bond distances in the optimised structures did not match the values observed in the crystal structure very well, the lower bounds of bond-length deviations correspond to the low-spin states of 1 and 1 + . For instance, the Fe-N1 bond length and the Fe-C1-N1 bond angle are only reproduced with sufficient accuracy by the low-spin states of both 1 and 1 + (+0.08 √Ö and +0.4-0.9¬∞, respectively), whereas all higher spin states systematically feature larger values for both internal coordinates (+0.41-0.49 √Ö and +9.6-19.0¬∞, respectively). At the same time, in the optimised low-spin states of 1 and 1 + , the Fe-N5 bond length is more strongly underestimated (-0.21-0.23 √Ö) than in the higher spin states (-0.11-0.14 √Ö). However, this deviation, although significant, is still small compared to that observed for the Fe-N1 bond length and might originate from the truncation of the protein backbone to the Nmethylimidazole ligand.

For all optimised structures, we observe that the N1 atom moves slightly out of the porphyrin plane, which is not observed for the crystal structure. We also observe that the torsional angles Fe-C1-C2-O and N3-Fe-N5-C3 deviate significantly between the crystal and optimised structures. The latter torsional angle describes the rotational orientation of the N-methylimidazole ligand. To study the effect of the imidazole orientation on the out-of-plane porphyrin nitrogen atom N1, we carried out a scan of the N3-Fe-N5-C3 torsional angle (36 steps of 10¬∞, PBE//PBE) while relaxing all other degrees of freedom. We find that the N1-N2-N3-N4 torsional angle (representing the out-of-plane character) does not change significantly (10.2¬∞-11.5¬∞ for 1 and 10.8¬∞-12.0¬∞ for 1 + versus 0.2¬∞ in the crystal structure).

Furthermore, we studied the correlation of the Fe-C1-C2-O and N3-Fe-N5-C3 torsional angles of both 1 and 1 + by performing three constrained structure optimisations (PBE//PBE), where we fixed (a) the first, (b) the second, and (c) both torsional angles while relaxing all other degrees of freedom. We find that the electronic-energy difference between the fully optimised structure, Eel, and the third constrainedly optimised structure, Eel,c, can be approximated by the sum of the electronic-energy differences between the fully optimised structure and each of the first two constrainedly optimised structures, Eel,a and Eel,b, respectively, i.e., Eel -Eel,c ‚âà (Eel -Eel,a) + (Eel -Eel,b). The error is smaller than 0.2 kJ mol -1 , which we consider negligible. We conclude that the rotational orientation of the N-methylimidazole ligand has a negligible effect on the reactivity of the carbene carbon atom.

div.head: S13
div.p: For PBE0, we find equivalent structural deviations from the crystal structure compared to PBE (Supplementary Table 11). We conclude that the low-spin states of both 1 and 1 + are favoured in terms of thermochemistry and molecular structure. Consequently, we will consider the singlet state of 1 and the doublet state of 1 + in the following analysis.

div.head: Stability of the End-On IPC Complex
div.p: For the construction of the low-spin states of the neutral, 2, and the cationic, 2 + , IPC complexes in the endon configuration, we performed relaxed scans of the C1-N1 bond in both low-spin structures of 1 and 1 + , and optimised the minimum-energy structures. Starting from the optimised low-spin states of 2 and 2 + , we performed structure optimisations of the intermediate-spin and high-spin states, respectively. Note that we cannot compare structural parameters in this case as the X-ray diffraction experiment only exhibits a bridged complex.

For 2 (Supplementary Table 12), our PBE//PBE results suggest that the singlet state is significantly more stable than the triplet (44.6-48.6 kJ mol -1 ) and quintet (125.4-136.0 kJ mol -1 ) states compared to 1 (8.5-13.0 kJ mol -1 and 63.5-71.2 kJ mol -1 , respectively). We find a similar but expectedly less pronounced preference for the singlet state of 2 for B3LYP*//PBE (20.0-24.0 kJ mol -1 and 75.5-86.2 kJ mol -1 compared to the triplet and quintet states, respectively). In the case of PBE0//PBE, the triplet state is effectively as stable as the singlet state (-2.8-1.4 kJ mol -1 stability gain/loss), whereas the quintet state is less stable than the singlet state by 30.1-41.4 kJ mol -1 . As we have discussed, the high exact-exchange admixture of 25% in PBE0 biases spin-state energy splittings in favour of higher spin states. Hence, our results indicate that the singlet state of 2 is clearly favoured over its quartet and sextet states.

For 2 + (Supplementary Table 13), the preference of the low-spin state is even more pronounced. Here, the results of all density functionals clearly suggest that the doublet state is more stable than the quartet (>51.8 kJ mol -1 ) and sextet (>74.4 kJ mol -1 ) states.

div.head: Interconversion Between the Bridged and the End-On Complex
div.p: Next, we studied the interconversion between the bridged and end-on configurations of the IPC complex (for a summary, see Supplementary Table 15). We determined the transition states between 1 and 2 (TS1,2), and 1 + and 2 + (TS + 1,2). Subsequently, we performed an intrinsic-reaction-coordinate scan to confirm the correspondence between both configurations. Relative energies of both reactions are listed in Supplementary Tables 15 and 16.

For PBE//PBE, we find that 2 is slightly more stable than 1 (9.7-19.0 kJ mol -1 ), and that TS1,2 is only 26.4-31.2 kJ mol -1 higher in energy than 1. A striking feature of the thermochemical data is that the difference in the vibrational entropy is quite pronounced between 2 and TS1,2 (TSvib = 8.5 kJ mol -1 ), even though their molecular structures are distinctly closer to each other compared to 1 and TS1,2. As the lowfrequency modes dominate the vibrational entropy, the harmonic-oscillator description may fail if these modes correspond to shallow potentials.

Contrary to the bridged-end-on interconversion of the neutral IPC complex, our PBE//PBE results suggest that 1 + is significantly more stable than 2 + (46.1-65.0 kJ mol -1 ), and that the activation energy for the isomerisation of 1 + to 2 + is distinctly higher (72.5-81.0 kJ mol -1 ). Again, we find a pronounced difference in the vibrational entropy (TSvib = 13.5 kJ mol -1 ) between 2 + and TS + 1,2. Noteworthy, we studied the effect of a polarizable environment on the molecular structure, electronic energy, and charge-density distribution of the cationic complexes. For this purpose, we repeated the structure optimisations of 1 + and 2 + embedded in a polar continuum solvent (water). The bond lengths listed in Supplementary Table 11, the electronic-energy difference between the bridged IPC complex and its end-on isomer, and the partial charges did not change by more than 0.1 √Ö, 1 kcal mol -1 , and 0.02 elementary charges, respectively.

In the majority of cases, the relative electronic energy is the dominant term of all thermodynamic energy differences considered in this work (see, e.g., Tables S15 and S16). Other energy contributions are only comparable in magnitude if the electronic-energy difference is already quite small (<20 kJ mol -1 ). Hence, the standard model of gas-phase thermochemistry works sufficiently well, even electronic-energy differences would suffice if a suitable error margin for density functionals is taken into account.

In the case of Fe(II), the average difference between total-energy measures for a given density functional is of similar magnitude compared to the energy difference when changing the density functional (‚àº10-20 kJ mol -1 ). While the magnitude of the former quantity is preserved in the case of Fe(III), PBE0//PBE leads to an energy-difference increase of 57.2 kJ mol -1 between 1 + and 2 + compared to PBE//PBE. Such a pronounced deviation of reaction-energy differences indicates that the PBE and PBE0 potential-energy surfaces are not compatible in the case of Fe(III). Here, this incompatibility even leads to the absurd result that the PBE0//PBE transition state between 1 + and 2 + , TS + 1,2, is lower in energy than 2 + . Noteworthy, we observe high spin contamination of about 53% in the Kohn-Sham determinant of 2 + for PBE0//PBE (Supplementary Table 14). Even though spin annihilation as implemented in Gaussian 09 eliminates spin contamination almost entirely (which does not imply correct density matrices, and hence, reliable electronic-energy expectation values), a fraction of about 5% spin contamination remains in the case of 2 + PBE0//PBE.

We compared the PBE//PBE results for Fe(III) with those of the PBE0//PBE(0) approximation, where the latter refers to PBE0 single-point energy calculations on a PBE0 potential-energy surface in the case of intermediate states and on a PBE potential-energy surface in the case of transition states (Supplementary Table 16). With this choice, we can resolve the absurd situation observed for PBE0//PBE where the approximate enthalpy difference of TS + 1,2 is lower than that of 2 + . While all approximate enthalpy differences compared to 1 + become larger in magnitude for PBE0//PBE(0), the reaction mechanism is qualitatively preserved, i.e., the ranking of approximate enthalpy differences remains the same.

div.head: Formation of the IPC Complex
div.p: While we find the low-spin state of 3 + (PBE-optimised) to be lower in energy than its high-spin state, EPR measurements clearly suggest a high-spin state. However, looking closer at the calculated results, we find that this structure is a pathological case for spin-state splittings, which are well known to depend strongly on the admixture of exact exchange. 18,21,22 In this case, we find 78.9 kJ mol -1 for the splitting with PBE (0% exact exchange), 30.0 kJ mol -1 with B3LYP* (15% exact exchange), and -10.9 kJ mol -1 with PBE0 (25% exact exchange; all data given refer to electronic-energy differences). Including thermal corrections further lowers the gap by 7.0 kJ mol -1 (ÔÅÑHapprox = 23.0 kJ mol -1 for B3LYP*//PBE). Gas-phase Gibbs free-energy differences even amount to 5.7 kJ mol -1 for the B3LYP*//PBE calculation, which is another clear sign that the calculations point to spin states that are very similar in energy. Hence, we may rely on the finding from EPR spectroscopy that the high-spin state of 3 + is the one that is (slightly) lower in energy. Note that the entropy change in the gas-phase Gibbs free-energy difference may be taken as an estimate for the condensed-phase entropy change of a spin crossover as discussed by Brehm 23 .

For the reaction of low-spin 3 + with EDA (formation of the IPC complex) to the end-on IPC complex 2 + , we find an activation barrier of 12.9 kJ mol -1 , which equals the energy difference between H2O + 2 + and EDA + 3 + . The reaction can be considered irreversible due to (i) loss of dinitrogen and (ii) rapid interconversion of 2 + to the thermodynamically more stable bridged IPC complex 1 + (59.6 kJ mol -1 lower in energy than 2 + ) through a considerably small unimolecular activation barrier of 14.4 kJ mol -1 . In this paragraph, all energy differences refer to approximate enthalpy differences.

div.head: Reactions of the IPC Complex with EDA and Styrene
div.p: To study the reactivity of the bridged and end-on Fe(II) and Fe(III) complexes, we examined their reactions with EDA and styrene. For a summary of the corresponding reaction mechanisms, see Supplementary Figure 20.

In all cases, we find that the bridged complexes 1 and 1 + form adducts with both EDA and styrene (reactions C1, D1, E1, and F1 in Tables S17-20, respectively), before the products are formed through a barrier-free reaction path. These adducts are characterised by a covalent bond between the carbene carbon atom of the IPC complex and one of the porphyrin nitrogen atoms, and by a covalent bond between the IPC carbene carbon atom and the carbene carbon atom of EDA or one of the two olefin carbon atoms of styrene. The adducts are less stable than the reactants (52.2-196.2 kJ mol -1 for PBE//PBE and 21.0-144.4 kJ mol -1 for PBE0//PBE), but an equilibrium with the reactant state (favouring the latter) is not expected due to the spontaneous formation of the products.

For both PBE//PBE and PBE0//PBE, we observe that the Gibbs free-energy difference, ‚àÜG, is significantly larger than the approximate enthalpy difference, ‚àÜHapprox, regarding the adduct formation (46.5-71.6 kJ mol -1 ). This distinct increase can be attributed mostly to the translational and rotational entropy differences, which arise from the different numbers of molecules in the reactant and adduct states (two versus one) through the transformation of three translational and three rotational degrees of freedom to six vibrational degrees of freedom. However, in a spatially confined system such as the protein-embedded IPC complex, this effect can be expected to be much weaker and, therefore, it will probably not blur the system-inherent electronic energetics at 0 K. This artificial energy-increasing effect has already been discussed in a study by us in 2002 24 .

Combined with the expected bias of vibrational entropy (dominated by low-frequency modes) and the fact that the electronic-entropy difference is zero for a given potential-energy surface, we conclude that the approximate enthalpy difference, ‚àÜHapprox, derived from the standard model of gas-phase thermochemistry is suitable for the description of the protein-embedded IPC complex. Note that in the standard model of gas-phase thermochemistry, the translational entropy is the only thermochemical energy contribution that is an effective function of the volume. Hence, for all chemical species in solution, one would need to correct the translational entropy according to Strans,solution = Strans + RT ln(y/ysolution), where RT ln(y/ysolution) = -7.9 kJ mol -1 for a solution-phase concentration of ysolution = 1.0 mol L -1 (Supplementary Table 6). Due to the neglect of entropic contributions in our thermochemical analysis, we do not consider this correction here.

Independent of the reactant (EDA or styrene) and the formal oxidation state of iron, we find significant activation energies for the formation of the adducts (‚àÜHapprox = 128.5-200.9 kJ mol -1 for PBE//PBE and ‚àÜHapprox = 120.8-200.5 kJ mol -1 for PBE0//PBE). For the end-on complexes 2 and 2 + (Tables S21 and S22), we do not find the formation of adducts with either EDA or styrene, but rather the immediate formation of the products via a low-energy transition path (‚àÜHapprox = 18.8-19.7 kJ mol -1 for 2 + EDA and ‚àÜHapprox = 33.2-40.5 kJ mol -1 for 2 + styrene) or even through a barrier-free reaction in the case of 2 + + EDA and 2 + + styrene, respectively. Similar results were found for the reaction of EDA with an Fe(II) IPC complex having a proximal SCH3 -ligand instead of N-methylimidazole 25 .

For both the bridged and end-on complexes, we find that the reaction with EDA is highly exothermic (‚àÜHapprox = 256.2-315.8 kJ mol -1 for PBE//PBE and ‚àÜHapprox = 303.2-420.0 kJ mol -1 for PBE0//PBE). Furthermore, our results suggest that the reaction with styrene is less (but still highly) exothermic compared to EDA (‚àÜHapprox = 139.5-199.1 kJ mol -1 for PBE//PBE and ‚àÜHapprox = 163.1-279.9 kJ mol -1 for PBE0//PBE).

We conclude that the bridged complexes 1 and 1 + are inert towards both EDA and styrene compared to the end-on complexes 2 and 2 + . Given that the initial reaction mixture consists of 3 + (catalytic amounts) plus reactant without reducing agent, the formation of 2 + occurs immediately based on our PBE//PBE data (rate constants were obtained from approximate enthalpy differences and Eyring's transition state theory). The pre-equilibration between 1 + and 2 + leads to a very small and temporarily constant concentration of 2 + (according to our PBE//PBE results, the relative population density of 2 + compared to 1 + would be 3.7 √ó 10 -11 ). Therefore, the rate of the reaction of 2 + plus reactant would be of pseudo-first order. According to Eyring's transition state theory, the corresponding effective bimolecular rate constant (the product of the bimolecular rate constant and the constant concentration of 2 + ) amounts to kbi,eff = 9.0 √ó 10 -3 s -1 for an initial 3 + concentration of 10 -5 mol L -1 (actual experimental conditions). By contrast, the value of the unimolecular rate constant corresponding to the isomerisation of 1 + to 2 + amounts to kuni = 6.7 √ó 10 -1 s -1 . In this case, product formation would be the rate-determining step of the overall reaction. Clearly, one should assess this kinetic analysis with caution since the barrier-free product formation would require consideration of non-equilibrium rate theories. There exist simple empirical expressions for rate constants of barrier-free reactions, which work well for small-molecule solution chemistry 26 . Assuming water as solvent, the resulting rate constant represents an effective activation barrier of 2.6 kJ mol -1 in Eyring's transition state theory, which lowers the predicted product-formation rate only by a small factor of less than 3. However, the actual IPC complex is embedded in a protein environment, which functions as a complex diffusion Supplementary Table 3. Therefore, it is not sensible to derive conclusions about the absolute value of kbi,eff based on our computational data. Still, the value of kbi,eff we calculated can be considered an upper bound to the observable rate constant, and we may safely assume that diffusion of EDA and styrene to the IPC complex determines the rate of the overall reaction. This hypothesis is also supported by the pseudo-first order consumption rate of 3 + (through reaction with EDA) that was found in our experiments (cf. Supplementary Figure 4B).
